author: {'steamid': '76561198020169423', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1407727243}
review:
This game has made some serious improvements since the last time I played it. I played it back in the early stages of it, and let's just say the game was a trainwreck. No team balance, getting new parts was fairly hard due to the low income of credits and whatnot, but now this game is AMAZING! Definitely a 10/10 in my book, as well as being listed as a must-play title. It's not Pay-to-Win since people can still get the same parts for their robots with or without paying for the game, and the people who play tend to be very friendly. Also, this game is VERY fast-paced, the matches only last for like 2-5 minutes and they're over when one team completed their objective OR if one entire team of robots have been destroyed. Give the game a whirl, it's F2P, and it's less than a gigabyte, so even if you don't necessarily like the game, you won't waste too much of your time waiting for it to download.

Biggest attractions of this game:
-Customization is flawless (countless modules including guns and chasis and heads and etc.)
-Team balance is pretty good
-Community is pretty funny
-Controls are fairly easy
-A shooter with Robots
-Lovely achievements
-All currencies are easily obtained while playing the game
-FREE TO PLAY!

Somewhat of a bummer:
-No gamepad support (YET)
-Takes a while to get certain parts to upgrade your modules without paying for them with premium currency (Sparks)
-Very small bagspace
-Only 2 free Robot slots, and it's 85 Sparks to get the third slot (not sure about how much it is to buy anymore)

author: {'steamid': '76561198055780622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1408015620}
review:
Guns and Robots can best be described as World of Tanks meets Loadout. Let me explain why:

It uses the World of Tanks method of resolving objectives. If you blow up, that's it, you're out. If everyone on one side dies, the game is over. The objective rarely is considered in most matches because of this. It also uses the idea of disarming an opponent based on where you shoot. Shoot the feet, you slow the opponent. Shot the arms, you disarm it. Shoot the head, you impair it's vision.

It's like Loadout in that, in order to succeed, you have to experiment with your build. There are a sea of different parts, whcih are used to make modules, the components of your robot. Each robot is made up of one chassis, one engine, one body type, one battery (or two), one head unit, and 2 to 4 weopons and weapon frames. This means you can tailer the bot to match your strategy as much as you wish. To make this more absurd, you can equipt up to two devices, which allow you to pull the game to your advantage.

Also like loadout, you ave to buy every part. Unlike Loadout, however, there is a limited inventory for each part, and each part can only be used on one robot at a time, so you are encouraged to just have one, with a few spare pieces to mmix it up a few times.

In short, it's intense, it's annoying, but once you deal with it, it can be a really good game. Or a really bad one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082115689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1407190273}
review:
OMG, this is a master piece :D The game is mega addicting and the pace of the game is really up to you. You can play the game in any style you like: rush, tank, stealth, tactical, etc. A large variety of weapon choice, although the meta guns are there and they usually work better than other guns. There is some teamwork involved, and cover base shooter elements in this game.

YET, there is one huge problem. There is a really, literally, PAY 2 WIN factor, but it's not any kind of pay to win, you will probablly need to pay a gigantic amount of money to do this. There are crates/boxes (random drop or bought with real money) in this game and they can be opened with paid "keys" (paid with real money). 3 of these crates contain unique weapons that can't be bought with in game currency, but the most expensive crate contains 2 completely op equipment.

The 2 equipment allows the robot to have carry extra guns. Standard robots, bought/built with in game currency, can have up to 2 or 4 guns. But these 2 equipments allows the robots to have double or triple the amount of guns comparing to a standard robot, although damage is reduce, due to the increase amount of guns, the damage is still doubled. When used with projectile base guns, these op equipments allows much larger amount of space being under fired.

The pay 2 win problem right now is not common and you can rarely see it, but when you do see it, it's instant gg. unlike most so call pay 2 win games, those gives a slight advantage, but this gives an obvious "you will stand no chance against a paid robot" kind of advantage.

*I will rate this as neutral if I can since the open season event*

Pros:
+Free :D
+Great art
+Large variety of weapons, body parts
+Some cover base shooter elements
+Interesting maps
+Pay 2 win situations are not common
+Really fun and addictive
+Queue mini game, wtf :D

Cons:
-Pay 2 win situations although not common, the game turns absolutely discoruaging when such situation does happen
-Unstable server
-Buggy, not critical
-Can do a better job on UI
-Some achievements can not be achieved yet
-Balance between guns are really off *but all available to the public*

For now, the game is great and I really recommend it, but when the day where pay 2 win is common, just uninstall this...

author: {'steamid': '76561198135022504', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1414910926}
review:
Guns and Robots - free-to-play игра, в которой нам предстоит взять на себя роль ни какого-то там человека, а робота. Так как в нашем распоряжении будет робот, то в наличии и соответствующая кастомизация: новый двигатель, новая пушка и т.д. Кастомизация довольно неплохая и даст размахнуться. Но изменения нужны не для красоты, а для того, чтобы не разлететься на винтики в бою. 

Касаемо боев, имеется всего три режима: Team Dethmatch, Bomb Squad (Уничтожение вражеской базы), Capture the Batteries (Захват флага). Негусто, конечно. Но это не единственный минус. Поражает и скоротечность боев. Если вы зашли в первый раз, то сражение может закончиться для вас за 30 секунд. Даже если вы наиграли долгое время, все равно больше 3 минут бой не пройдет. Никаких возрождений, только одна жизнь. 

Что еще разочаровывает - отсутствие выбора режимов. Игра сама решает в какой режим вам требуется играть. Тут нет рандома, все виды боя идут по порядку. Поэтому вы сможете опробовать себя в каждом. 

Так как игра free-to-play, то должна быть и валюта за реальные деньги. И она тут есть, но пока не вносит дисбаланс. Донатная валюта нужна для расширения слотов, использования топовых снарядов для орудий, покупки деталей, дабы не копить виртуальную валюту.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961138963', 'num_games_owned': 1138, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1418689375}
review:
A concise review...of course, mileage may vary (different people have different experiences, values, and expectations which will result in different opinions):

[b]PROS[/b]:
[list]
[*]Great art style
[*]Good combat mechanic
[*]Good bot custom creation system (except for upgrading parts, which is one of the worst in any game I've played, see below).
[*]Devs are active in the community
[/list]
[b]CONS:[/b]
[list]
[*]Most importantly right now: In-game purchases of boosts (credits for example) DO NOT WORK. The devs are aware of this complaint but insisted it is working fine. I have evidence to the contrary (several screenshots during and after the 24hr boost, there is [b]no difference[/b] in credit gain whatsoever. It was a wasted purchase.
[*]Tutorial is severely lacking (lobby chat has a never ending supply of new players asking what to do, how to build a robot, etc.) 
[*]Limited to small skirmishes of 5 v 5 (some may not necessarily mind this, but for others, it just feels to small, too "quick."
[*]It's very common for players to go AFK because they get rewarded either way (even if it is a loss). This creates a serious imbalance in the small 5 v 5 match.
[*]VERY limited inventory space (devs want you to buy more), which means there isn't much room for customizing or building bots. Creativity is discouraged.
[*]The price increases (it isn't static) if you want to increase your inventory. Again, another discouragment of creativity.
[*]Player is nickel-and-dimed for almost everything imaginable in game (customization, extra space, being able to form a squad/group with more than 2 players), etc.
[*]Chat Lobby has no filter, there is no way to mute/ignore/ban players (people spam porn sites and obscenities quite a bit, again, screenshots taken).
[*]Upgrading your parts is expensive, yet adds very little value. Almost all parts gain minimal durability and durability only. Each part already has numerous properties, but none (w/ exception of damage for just a few weapons) ever get upgraded. It's absurd IMO as a higher tier part ought to have a relevant increase in quality...in Guns and Robots however, it does not.
[*]You get random bonus chests at time, but have to pay [b]a lot[/b] of sparks (purchased with real cash) to unlock them.
[/list]

[b]Summary[/b]

The game is worth playing as long as the player understands that this is a game in which the player is expected to spend quite a bit of money to enjoy the full experience. However, spending money in-game (vs DLC Starter Pack) just doesn't work (for me) and the devs don't seem to be concerned with it.

It's a game I'd play casually, for kicks, but would not recommend to friends and definitely would not recommend spending money on, a lesson learned the hard way after purchasing the Starter Pack and spending sparks in-game. It's a cash grab through and through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995142915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1407444207}
review:
its not bad...
borderlands 1 gfx
customisable robots
rounds last 5 minutes so ok for quick blasts

downside....

seems very pay to win
seems overly grindy - eg... Ive got 1 daily task to do... need to do 15k damage in total have 20 hrs to do it....to do this your going to have to put in at least 8 hrs....
Objectives are arbitrary.... most rounds over in a couple of minutes - once all 5 robots are dead = gg
Commnication implementation was designed by sum1 with no friends.... its virtually non existent.
in 12 games i got no sparks.... you need 10 sparks to get extra inv slots... otherwise your stuck with just 1 robot....
For all the above reasons..... i say dont play this.....it needs work....

however... i am enjoying coming on and playing a round inbetween waiting for DOTA  to find me a US game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198059040174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1408127656}
review:
ゲームスピードはゆったりした感じのギャグっぽいロボゲー

ロボのカスタマイズもさほど難しくなく、パーツ単価が低いので序盤からパーツを組み替える楽しさが味わえる。
フィールドのいたるオブジェクトが破壊可能だったり、
ロボの動作が割とリアルで、安っぽいゲームではない印象。

十字砲火されても割と動けるし、すぐには壊れないのでハメられてムキーーーっとなるような事は今のところなさそう。
マッチングもスムーズで、１試合も短いので気軽に遊べる。

author: {'steamid': '76561198107211274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1408152808}
review:
well well this game is GOOD this is a third person shooter game BUT with customizable robots it has so many weapons to chose from like well a OP ASS rocket launcher and snipar rifle etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056623366', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1407334424}
review:
Okay let's make this short and sweet

this game would be great if they fixed the progression system
there is no incentive to upgrade your robot at all, the weapons are the same and stat increase from the initial upgrades are pretty poor yet grant you big enough repair bill to make you regret it. 
The game isn't exactly play to win as it tries VERY hard to match you up against people your rank. 

The actual gameplay is fun.
overall I would recommend don't upgrade past rank 2 and just have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198115771650', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1414933112}
review:
Gran juego. Por la estetica me recuerda a borderlands.
Vayamos paso a paso en este juego.
 
El juego trata sobre crear tu propio robot con una variedad increible de objetos.

Las batallas no suelen durar mucha mas de 5 minutos eso esta bien para echar partiditas rapidas.

Hay varios modos de juegos como lucha a muerte en equipo, capurar la bandera (la bateria en este caso) y colocar la bomba en el totem enemigo.

Hay un sistema de subida de niveles que me parece bastante bueno aparte de que se consiguen muchas cosas rapidamente tambien mediante logros.

La unica pega que veo es el inventario que necesita sparks para aumentarlo y que se comparte con varios robots eso deberian rebajarlo un poco.

El juego acaba de salir por lo que nos esperan muchas cosas mas. Creo que tiene un buen futuro.

¿Mi puntuacion?

4/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198020838155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1416779884}
review:
Tons of fun, is currently having some major issues dealing with, well I'm not sure, launch?  There were 10-19 people in queue for 3 runs in a row and in all 3 runs it paired us up in 2v2s instead of 5v5 which is the default.  Which are ok, but much less fun.  Needs to be more chasis etc to choose from, but a decent selection to start off with.  Game bugged out and I couldn't close menus or exit.  Worked completely fine last night and I had a blast.  8.0/10 last night,  6.0/10 until they fix stuff.

To warn, there's a fairly sizable 'pay to play' barrier it looks like once you get beyond the early stages of the game.  You'd have to play like 200 matches just to expand your starting 25 slots of inventory just to get another 5 slots. 25 slots is enough for 2 full bots with no/a couple extra parts  And you HAVE to have a 2nd bot to play because your other bot goes inactive while it's upgrading.  This game could be amazing, I mean hugely tons of fun, but the implementation needs some major tweaking...and a lot more players.

I've made edits to my review after the most recent patch.  Which in theory has attempted to alleviate the inventory issues, but simultaneously has me stuck at a loading screen so now I can't play at all.  Devs have acknowledged the issue and are working on it.

review:
パーツを組み合わせて、ぼくのかんがえたさいきょうのロボットが作れるTPS
カジュアルでとっつきやすい
制限重量内であれば軽量級と中量級、重量級のパーツを混ぜて使うことが出来る
ゲーム内マネーは実績などで多く手に入り、パーツが安価なためさまざまな構成を試せる

欠点としては以下がある
5vs5と対戦人数が少ない
使える武器と使えない武器の差が激しい
拡張しないとインベントリーの最大所持数が少ない

--追記--
8/11 初期の最大所持数が増えて、1段階目の拡張が簡単に行えるようになったので所持数はマシになった

author: {'steamid': '76561197970740383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1407178226}
review:
Le concept est intéressant bien que pomper sur un vieu jeu qui date de l'atari stf de pouvoir créer un robot et de le faire combattre et au milieu de ça on y ajouter une ambiance far west et des lance-roquettes (hmmm?), le graphisme est plutôt pas mal mais l'interface du menu est mal agencer du coup on s'y perd un peu. 
Le jeu s'apparente plus à du World Of Tanks au niveau du rythme de jeu et d'action.
Comme souvent sur Steam pas de traduction française (non je ne dis pas que c'est leur faute pour autant).
Tout s'achète les munitions, réparation, pièces de robots et du peu que j'ai joué on rentre peu voir pas dans ces frais.
Bref grosse déception mais qui sait peut-être évoluera-t-il dans un bon sens... A suivre à l'occasion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042588873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1407203291}
review:
The concept behind the game is simple enough and quite appealing: build a goofy robot out of random scrap and junk, strap some equally goofy weapons to it like dynamite launchers, bootleg laser guns and acid filled water balloons, and then send it out to go blow up stuff. It's rather cartoony, doesn't take itself all that seriously, and in theory would be a fun quick-fix sort of game.

In practice though, there are a lot of imbalances and glaring issues that ruin the fun. The main offender is the upgrading. You have to upgrade your robot's parts and weapons to stay competitive, but it's not just a matter of paying some coins and waiting for the upgrade to finish like other games of this type. You also have to have upgrade components which can only be found randomly as post-match rewards or bought outright with premium currency (aka the cash shop), and if you don't feel like buying them then you're going to be stuck waiting a very long time for enough components to do anything. This really kills the experimenting that should be a part of any game about robot building, as it makes you not want to invest in new parts or weapons. Having the timesink alone is more than enough to slow down upgrading, adding in the extra element of components just comes across as a very cynical cash grab attempt.

Weapon balance is also another problem, as too often one player can steamroll an entire team by themselves just because they managed to build a heavy bot with four launcher arms. Supposedly battery power and weight limits have a limiting effect, but since launcher rounds travel in a straight line and not an arc, it seems all too easy to just build something that can tank all the opposition's fire and spray AoE misery right into their faces.

And finally, there are a number of overall fit-and-finish oversights that left a sour impression. The tutorial gives only the very barest of detail on how to build a robot and doesn't give even a basic explanation of how weight limits, battery power or engine choices affect your movement and ability to use your weapons. A lot of features can only be found by just clicking around and stumbling onto them. Even some very basic functions aren't working right: there's an achievement for renaming your robot, but at the time of writing this you can't even do that. Shouldn't the things tied to achievements at least be checked to make sure they're not broken?

There's a fun idea here, but the game loses its appeal quickly and still feels like it needs a lot more work before it's ready to be played more than once out of curiosity.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960693835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1407884103}
review:
Updated Review for Post Week 1 Patch

A week has gone by and a lot of stuff has changed for the better with Guns and Robots.

Half of that was the developers rebalancing of how you earn sparks, and the other half was me learning more about how the game works and how I should be playing it. 

In order to save time I am just going to go over each of my "Bad" points from the last review and explain why it’s not an issue anymore:

The Bad:
- Only 5vs5 players - Well this actually makes the game quick and sweet and feels really balanced.

- 1 LIFE PER GAME - Again I was wrong about this, after playing this game for several more hours I can honestly say the game is over so fast it doesn't matter.

- Game starts you with a full inventory - Now the devs give you multiple ways to get a lot of sparks when you start playing the game (daily challenges, round rewards, and with every achievement) and you can spend them all to get a decent number of inventory slots out of the gate.

- With the limited inventory it makes it almost impossible to buy parts and experiment - I now realize that the way the game is MENT to be played is that you buy parts, try them, and if you don’t like them, sell them and try something else. I have only played a week and now have well over $50 000, and each part is usually $200, so it is not an issue to buy and sell parts to keep your inventory clean. 

- The interface for making your robot is cumbersome – I did say you get used to it, and I have.

- When you combine parts into "modules" the part is considered IN USE. And you cannot use that same part on another robot that you make – This is still an issue which I touch on in the video… If I like the head, chest and legs of a robot, why can I not use them to make a second one just to change up the guns? It would save time assembling & disassembling them etc. 

- YOUR ROBOT IS LOCKED INTO A MATCH UNTIL ITS OVER – The matches usually last 3 minutes, so this was never really an issue, just my first impression.  

- I am getting matched up with players that seem to have hundreds more health than me and way more powerful weapons – This isn’t really true… There are many classes of robots and gun types… some robot builds still do tare through me, but I tare through other as well. It is one of the good things about this game :)

So there you have it! I was wrong about some of my early impressions, and the devs made a great move when they started giving people sparks early on through achievements so that they could increase their inventory.

All in all, in its current state I can recommend this game as a fun and addictive casual free to play shooter. 

Heere is an updated video review impressions... thing!


http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=299926564

----------------------------------------------------

I have only played this game for 2 hours. So I don't feel comfortable reviewing it. But I will post some of my observations here.

The Good:
- Robots have personality
- You can customize every part to make the robot of your dreams
- Many different kinds of weapons, feet, chests, heads, and devices (gadgets likes mines, etc.)
- The clubhouse where you make the robots is a cool place for the main menu
- You get 1 cash currency every couple of matches to lessen the hurt (explained later)
- HATS
- Levels/maps are varied and look nice 
- The overall game has personality bursting from it really
- The leveling up is satisfying and you get currency, and materials needed to upgrade equipment when you level.

The Bad:
- Only 5vs5 players

- 1 LIFE PER GAME - this game more than anything needs to allow you to fight and die over and over again to see what is good/bad about your build. But much like World of Tanks, you only get 1 life per match AND your robot is locked until the match finished. But alteast WoT gives you multiple tanks to start, this game... only gives you one. 

- Game starts you with a full inventory, and you need to use the real cash currency [sparks] to expand it. 

- With the limited inventory (which requires real cash currency [sparks] to expand) it makes it almost impossible to buy parts and experiment with making new robots without playing hundreds of rounds to get "sparks".

- The inerface for making your robot is combersome and takes longer than it should making it a chore. (You do get used to it though)

- When you combine parts into "modules" the part is considered IN USE. And you can not use that same part on another robot that you make.

- You only start off with 2 slots to make robots and again, YOUR ROBOT IS LOCKED INTO A MATCH UNTIL ITS OVER, so you're left sitting there until its over, which really sucks. Atleast in World of Tanks they give you 5 tanks to screw around with, not just 1. 

- Its Day 1, I should be being matched with new players, instead I am getting matched up with players that seem to have hundreds more health than me and way more powerful weapons.

- Leveling up equipment takes real world time. This sucks but is in a lot of F2P games...

Final verdict: Like I said this is not a review. I've only played for two hours so if you don't feel that you can trust my words on it, well there you go. 

I honestly feel like the game is limiting you with the limited inventory. I feel like the inventory is needed to allow player to truely customize their robots freely.  And since that is the main draw of this game, I feel bad :(

The good free to play games out there don't do that, they don't ask for money for gameplay required items, and inventory in this type of game is a MUST. I don't know, I love its charm but hate it limits so early on while playing it (2 hours).... as of right now, I can't recommend it. 

If you had 100 slots, or unlimited slots this game would be a light hearted casual shooter that I would recommend to everyone who needs to kill 5 minutes at a time, but ... yeah.

Here's a video where I discuss pretty much everything concerning my opinions of the game: 

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=296796353

author: {'steamid': '76561197991068137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1407206524}
review:
At the end of the day this is a third person shooter with what appears to be a variety of customizable parts, cool weapons, and strategic maps.

However, after playing for a while you'll realize that there's actually very little customization at all and mostly combat ends up being two teams of people smash eachother together hammering their fire buttons until the tide turns in one direction or the other due to focused fire.

Weapons and components appear to have lots of stats, but more or less all end up being the same. One gun may have 10 damage for 3 shots per second, another 30 damage for 1 shot per second. They'll use about the same amount of energy per second and so on. There are differences but they're mostly minor. Different chasis have different speeds and some other stats, but mostly you're deciding if you want 4 arms (for higher DPS and lower sustained DPS) or 2 arms. That's about it. Light mechs dont seem to have much advatnage over heavies (they go faster, but not really MUCH faster).

All in all there are simply better games out there that deliver a higher degree of customization and strategy, ranging from more complex games like Mechwarrior Online to more similar ones like Robocraft.

review:
The controls are very clunky.  There is no testing area to try out the items you just bought.  This game expects you to just understand their system and think and not explain it.  

Main complaint: Why lock the movement orientation to what ever way you are facing?  You have a WASD to use.  You shouldn't have to adjust which button is actually forward depending on which way you are looking.  W should always be the way your feet are facing not the way your head is facing.
